name: jason
tagline: A minimal JSON parser, written in TypeScript
description: jason is a toy project for parsing and formatting JSON data. It is slower than the native JSON.parse(), but not by too large of a margin. It isn't too practical since JavaScript can already parse JSON, but it was interesting to build

name: crisp
tagline: A little javascript minifier written in Rust, with zero dependencies
description: crisp uses a pretty basic lexer to tokenize the Javascript and then works directly off those tokens. This cuts out the middleman of a parser, with minimal impact on it's output (maybe a couple chars more)

name: koi
tagline: A tiny (180 bytes) template engine that gets right to the point!
description: koi is my attempt at something along the lines of a nanoid - a small utility that doesn't bring a ton of functionality, but still manages to be useful

name: leaphttp
tagline: A powerful, light micro-http framework, with a focus on an extendable plugin interface, and a great developer experience
description: Using the lessons that I learned from my last attempt at a similar project, I built leaphttp with much simpler internals and a more powerful external API

name: Stacc Analytics
tagline: Privacy-first analytics your users will love
description: This is a hackathon project, so I'm not too sure if it counts but whatever. We built a powerful analytics platform that gives you all the essential statistics, but without the privacy invasion that you don't. It totally doesn't use firebase which we didn't realize was a major flaw until after we built it... oops

name: onlinx
tagline: A fast, simple HTTP framework written in Typescript
description: So this was my technically my second go at an http framework, but kinda just a rebranding of the original onlinx. The internals aren't nearly as clean as leaphttp (so don't read the source), but the API is moderately okay. Also I apparently didn't know monorepos were a thing because I created a whole GitHub organization to house a grand total of one repo
